frame.name: Win_prize
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Competitor</fen> claims a <fen>Prize</fen> as a result of the outcome of their participation in a <fen>Competition</fen>. <fen>Competition</fen> is meant to be construed broadly to include cases where there is no skill involved as well as cases where there is no ranking of participants, and indeed does not require that there be multiple pariticipants or a definable end of game, as in the case of winning prizes at a carnival game. All that is required to be this kind of <fen>Competition</fen> is that there is some way of determining whether a <fen>Competitor</fen> will receive the <fen>Prize</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Competitor">We</fex> <t>won</t> <fex name="Prize">a car</fex> <fex name="Competition">in the raffle</fex>.</ex>
<ex></ex>
The use of win.v in this frame is similar to the Finish_competition frame, but there are a number of differences. Firstly, Win_prize focuses on what the <fen>Competitor</fen> receives as a result of their participation in a process. Unlike Finish_competition, Win_prize does not necessarily give any information about how a <fen>Competitor</fen> ranked relative to other competitors, or even if there is any system of ranking of competitors, or any end of the process that is defined as winning or losing. Win_prize only requires a system for determining which <fen>Prize</fen> or prizes go to a <fen>Competitor</fen>, if any. That is why the opposite of "I won (something)" in Win_prize is not "I lost", but rather "I didn't win anything".</def-root>

FE.name: Competitor
FE.definition: <def-root>The individual or individuals involved in the <fen>Competition</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Score
FE.definition: <def-root>A quantity whereby progress is measured during the game, and Rank and <fen>Prize</fen>s are awarded to the <fen>Competitor</fen> afterward.</def-root>

FE.name: Margin
FE.definition: <def-root>The amount by which the <fen>Competitor</fen> 's and <fen>Score</fen>s differ.</def-root>

FE.name: Rank
FE.definition: <def-root>The rank (according to <fen>Score</fen>) that a <fen>Competitor</fen> acheives.</def-root>

FE.name: Prize
FE.definition: <def-root>A socially and/or monetarily significant entity which is given to a <fen>Competitor</fen> according to <fen>Score</fen> or <fen>Rank</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Means
FE.definition: <def-root>An action of the <fen>Competitor</fen> that results in the outcome of the <fen>Competition</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Manner
FE.definition: <def-root>Any description of the <fen>Competitor</fen> which is not covered by more specific FEs, including epistemic modification (probably, presumably, mysteriously), secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). It may also indicate salient characteristics of a <fen>Competitor</fen> that also affect their action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully). </def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition: <def-root>When the <fen>Competition</fen> takes place.</def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition: <def-root>The location where the <fen>Competition</fen> takes place.</def-root>

FE.name: Venue
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE is for the named venue of a competition, particularly when the place has been built for the purpose of a <fen>Competition</fen>.
</def-root>

FE.name: Particular_iteration
FE.definition: <def-root>Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states. </def-root>

FE.name: Competition
FE.definition: <def-root>The event in which the <fen>Competitor</fen> competes.</def-root>

FE.name: Explanation
FE.definition: <def-root>The reason why the <fen>Competitor</fen> wins the <fen>Competition</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Period_of_iterations
FE.definition: <def-root>The length of time from when winning events began to be repeated to when they stopped.</def-root>

FE.name: Opponent
FE.definition: <def-root>The individual that the <fen>Competitor</fen> has been competing against.</def-root>

FE.name: Circumstances
FE.definition: <def-root>The state of the world when the <fen>Competitor</fen> wins the <fen>Competition</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Re-encoding
FE.definition: <def-root>The frame expressed by the target typically corresponds to a Means action within the frame expressed by the <fex name="Re-encoding">Re-encoding</fex>, but not necessarily. </def-root>

FE.name: Result
FE.definition: <def-root>The state-of-affairs that prevails as a result of the <fen>Competitor</fen> winning the <fen>Competition</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Iterations
FE.definition: <def-root>The frame element <fex name="Iterations">Iterations</fex> is used for expressions that indicate the number of times the <fen>Competitor</fen> wins the <fen>Competition</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Communicative_force
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE indicates the <fen>Communicative_force</fen> or authority with which the winning event operates (often denoted by words such as "officially," "formally," "technically," etc.). </def-root>

FE.name: Event_description
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE applies to appraisals of the event, typically a judgment of its expectedness, or a description of the state-of-affairs introduced by the winning event.</def-root>
